Journal Story: Before my epidural steroid injection this past Tuesday (9/7/21), I had given up on the idea of ever backpacking again.Â  After my consultation with the Pain Management Doctor, my thought processes changed, to where now I think, it could still be doable.
Once I do get back to the trail, I know a Thru-Hike won't be an option, however, I'm not ruling out the idea of a "Slow and Steady" section hike.

I know there have been older folks then me that have done the whole trail, and I tip my hat to them, but along with my age, there's the physical condition of my spine that might prevent me from doing the whole thing, and that's OK, "Any More, It Doesn't Matter" to me.I've stood on Katahdin twice and Springer Mountain Twice, and have covered a lot of the miles between these two mountains over the past 48 years.Â  I've experienced all sorts of trail weather, met some truly amazing interesting people, and some not so interesting, and have seen some beautiful scenery, that a lot of people will never see.As long as I can put one foot in front of the other, I'll keep backpacking, but it doesn't matter to me if I complete the trail.

In my Journal Details section under the heading "Start Date", I have May 11, 2022.Â  I've been giving this some thought.Â  Granted, my hiking style will be Section Hiking, and if I were to start at Harpers Ferry, the May date would be fine, however, I've been entertaining the idea of starting at Springer Mountain, and that date could easily be mid to late April and maybe later.I would like to avoid as much cold weather as possible, and since I'd just be section hiking, a date in May or even June could be planned.

When I opened up my Yahoo account this morning to check emails, I found this picture over in the sidebar.If my memory serves me correctly, the ATC was given 9.5 million dollars a year or two ago.Â  I don't recall exactly why they were given this sum of money, I think it was to do with a pipeline or something but being a Non-Profit Organization, that's still a pretty good chunk of change.So why do you suppose they are still asking for donations, when last year, they were telling hikers to Not come to the trail, and if they did, to stay out of the shelters?

For those of you that have been following along with me on this journal, I want to bring you up to date with whatâ€™s been happening.

I had planned on starting a Flip-Flop hike out of Harpers Ferry, W. Va., May 12th of this year, heading North to Katahdin, however, while hiking over in John Bryan State Park the Sunday before I was to leave, the condition I have in my spine decided to flare up which kept that from happening.

My Chiropractor had me to the point where I could walk without much of a gimp at all in my right leg, which excited me, knowing I was getting to return to the trail.

Usually, his adjustments worked wonders in restoring my mobility, that wasnâ€™t to be the case this time.Â  Granted, they helped for a short time, but I was needing something long-lasting if I was to return.Â  On one of my visits, he did some X-rays and found my right ilium bone had rotated out of position.

By July, my condition had worsened to where I couldnâ€™t walk at all except in a hunched-over position.Â  Standing for any length of time was out of the question and then sitting for long periods even became difficult.Â  The only relief I could find was lying in bed.

After an MRI, my doctor referred me over to the neurological department.Â  The MRI showed I had severe stenosis at L3-L4, along with some disk degeneration, disc bulges, protrusions, and extrusions. Â I had an appointment made but wasnâ€™t going to get in until August 24th.

I met with the same neurosurgeon I had in 2019 when I discovered I had problems with my spine.Â  In 2019, I was told he didnâ€™t want to do surgery yet.Â  In 2019, he had me go through physical therapy, which helped, but I was still gimpy.Â  This time, he wanted me to try epidural steroid injections, which I did, one on September 7th and another on September 21st.

When youâ€™re backpacking, you always reach â€œMilestonesâ€, be it the Â¼ of the way sign, Fontana Dam, Newfound Gap, Woods Hole Hostel, or Damascus, to name a few.Â  I reached a Milestone so to speak on September 24th, I was able to stand and walk erect after 2 Â½ months of walking hunched over.Â  Then on September 28th, I was able to stand in the shower, still in some pain, but bearable.

Iâ€™m now going to another Chiropractor/Physical Medicine Center here in town.Â  I had some shock therapy yesterday, and today will get some more, along with adjustments.Â  My hip has been hurting quite a bit, so perhaps the ilium bone needs to be set again.

Iâ€™m sure the burning and numbness in my right ankle is from a nerve being pinched, so hopefully, with some acupuncture, which they also have here, Iâ€™ll get relief from that.

I know there are those around us that live with pain every day, some, unfortunately, live with it until they die, and this indeed is a sad thing.Â  Perhaps itâ€™s some form of birth defect, or maybe the result of an accident, or war injury, or even a dreaded disease.

With that being said, the pain Iâ€™ve been dealing with since 2019, is the result of Spinal Stenosis, the narrowing of the space around the spinal cord where it passes through your vertebrae.Â  This narrowing is caused by the build-up of some form of matter.Â  This matter puts pressure on the nerves.

In my case, the nerves in my right leg are affected causing excruciating pain in my hip and ankle.Â  The ankle pain makes me want to favor my ankle, thus resulting in a gimped style of walking.Â  It also causes tightness on my right side, which makes me want to haunch over to relieve this discomfort.

I have loved hiking ever since I went on my first Boy Scout hike at the age of 11.Â  Even if I wasnâ€™t on an official Boy Scout hike, it wasnâ€™t anything for me to take off and start walking and perhaps be gone all day.Â  My parents never worried about me, I remember my mom telling another lady, â€œHe knows his way around the creeks and wood lots that he frequents and where and when to get a mealâ€.

I discovered the Appalachian Trail while attending a National Boy Scout Jamboree, as the Scoutmaster of my hometown Troop.Â  This was back in 1973, the year I made my first summit of Mount Katahdin.Â  I was in the workforce so every year when I had vacation time, I was on the trail doing a section of it.

Here it is, soon to be 47 years later, and Iâ€™m still wanting to hike this trail.Â  My love for hiking and being outdoors is just as strong now as it was on that first Boy Scout hike.

Iâ€™m told my gimpy leg and the pain associated with it, can be repaired with surgery, however, Iâ€™m told by the neurosurgeon that â€œheâ€ doesnâ€™t want to do it yet, which I didnâ€™t understand until the other day, is because of Medicare.

Apparently, Medicare wants doctors to exhaust all forms of alternative treatments before theyâ€™ll pay for surgery.Â  I did physical therapy in 2019, I had (2) epidural steroid injections in September, and have been seeing Chiropractors for the past 2 years.Â  Yesterday, I tried acupuncture for the first time and actually was pain-free, but it didnâ€™t last.

I never was one to â€œget a second opinionâ€, but this Thursday (10/14/21), Iâ€™m going to see another doctor in a different Medical Group than the one Iâ€™ve been using and see what they have to say.Â  Who knows, they may be able to fix me up good and proper so I can get back out on the trails.

With November well underway I know a lot of prospective â€œThru-Hikersâ€ begin their count down to when they will step foot on the trail.Â  Having said this, I want to wish these folks the Best of Luck on their journeys.

For me, Iâ€™m not sure what 2022 will offer as far as hiking.Â  Iâ€™m pretty sure a Thru-Hike will not be in my future, but one never knows.

A few weeks ago, I switched Chiropractors.Â  I found one here in town that along with doing adjustments also does â€œacupunctureâ€.Â  Four sessions of having pins stuck all over my body has not lessened my pain.

For those of you that have been following along with me in this journal, you know I started having problems with walking back in 2019 due to spinal stenosis.Â  My condition has progressively gotten worse to where if I wasnâ€™t so bullheaded, Iâ€™d have given up and become an invalid.

On a recent Chiropractor visit, after my adjustment, the doctor asked if I thought the adjustment did any good.Â  I replied, â€œI appreciate what youâ€™re trying to do Dr. Jeff, but I think my condition is beyond chiropractic careâ€.Â  He agreed with me and said he was referring me over to a neurosurgeon. 
Iâ€™m to see this neurosurgeon on December 10, just 3 days after my 70th Birthday.Â  If this doctor can restore my ability to walk â€œpain-freeâ€, Iâ€™ll consider this The Best Birthday Present Ever.

Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll have physical therapy to do should an operation be in store for me, so Iâ€™m hoping my bullheadedness will have me giving everything I got doing it.

Most of this year has been spent in idleness as far as biking and hiking goes, so I know Iâ€™m definitely out of shape.Â  The spare tire around my middle has increased by several pounds so Iâ€™m going to want to shed this weight, or at least part of it before hitting the trail.Â  I know the trail will take off weight without a problem.Â  On March 26, 2015, I weighed 223 pounds when I left Springer Mountain.Â  In Pearisburg, Va., I went to the hospital, I was having trouble with my right leg, they weighed me, I was down to 175 pounds and eating everything I got my hands on.

I notice I donâ€™t eat as much as I use to and thatâ€™s common with older folks.Â  I wonder how â€œtrail hungerâ€ will affect me. Â When backpacking, you burn up a lot of calories, so maybe Iâ€™ll turn into a lean, food-eating, hiking machine. (Actually, Iâ€™ll probably stay an Overweight, food-eating, slow but steady hiker).

Depending on how everything goes once I see the neurosurgeon, will determine when and if I start a hike in 2022. 
Stay tuned!!

This year has flown by so fast, it seems like just the other day I was making preparations for my Flip-Flop hike when actually it was back in May.

I didnâ€™t get much done in the way of exercising, as my spinal stenosis has progressively gotten worse, so much so that Iâ€™m in constant pain with every little move.

I met with a new neurosurgeon on December 10, and after a thorough examination, he thinks I might have a cervical vertebra that is blocking some nerves.Â  He ordered an MRI for that region as well as some X-rays of me standing erect. Iâ€™ll get these done on January 24. Â Once he has these results, heâ€™ll know what to do first as far as treatment.

He looked at the results of an earlier MRI I had done and said that the L3 and L4 were definitely showing signs of blockage and that surgery is necessary to correct them.

When I told him I enjoyed backpacking, he said, â€œIâ€™ll have you out backpacking next yearâ€.Â  These were words I was hoping to hear.

I still donâ€™t look to be a Thru-Hiker, but I sure would count it a blessing, to be a member of the Class of 2022 â€œBackpackersâ€!

Please check back for future updates.

Itâ€™s been a while since my last post, so I thought Iâ€™d write one today in order to bring everyone that actually reads my journal, up to date.
I had my other MRI done on January 24th.Â  This one was on my cervical area.Â  The results showed significate damage in that area. After meeting with my neurosurgeon, he has reason to believe that surgery there, â€œmightâ€ correct the problem Iâ€™m having with my Lumbar region.Â  He said we could give it a couple of months and if I was still having problems with my walking, then he would operate down there to correct it.Â  Iâ€™m to meet with him on May 11th to view the actual MRI CD images and to set up a date for surgery.

Iâ€™m being optimistic thinking that an operation on my cervical vertebrae, will do the trick so that I can still get a little hiking done this year.Â  I would also like to ride the â€œBike Trailâ€ from Cincinnati to Cleveland.Â  
Iâ€™ve been following the journals of a few 2022 Classmates, thus keeping my hopes and dreams alive with each mile they hike.

Any short hikes I could do locally would be awesome, but with my unsteady legs, I wouldnâ€™t want to do them alone.

The new Primary Care Physician I acquired on the first of this year has been simply amazing.Â  Before she even saw me for the first time, she ordered a prescription for Duloxetine which has worked wonders in relaxing my nerves.Â  I now can stand erect, I have no problems sleeping, and Iâ€™m in very little if any pain.Â  This medication was ordered after talking with me on the phone.

If â€œnoâ€ hiking this year is in my future, Iâ€™m entertaining the idea, even with the high cost of gasoline, to drive out to the trail somewhere to offer Trail Magic to anyone that would like it.Â  Iâ€™ll no more after my surgery.

Until thenâ€¦

Here we are, starting the month that signifies half of the year is almost gone.

The â€œClass of 2022 Thru-Hikersâ€ are spread out along the trail making their way either North or South.

Iâ€™m anxiously waiting for July 11th, the date I go in for Cervical surgery.Â  My neurosurgeon informed me that the disks in my C3/C4 and C5/C6 need to be removed, and replacements added.Â  He believes that correcting this problem may take care of the problems Iâ€™m having in the Lumbar region of my spine.Â  He said, we will give it a couple of months, and then if Iâ€™m still having problems with walking, we would repair the Lumbar vertebrae that are needing to be repaired.

In the meantime, Iâ€™m planning on taking a hiker from Madison, IN out to Harpers Ferry so that he can begin his â€œFlip-Flopâ€ hike.Â  Once he reaches Maine, I may drive up and get him, to bring him back to Harpers Ferry, so that he can hike the Southern half of the trail.

Iâ€™m not exactly sure when we will be heading over to HF, but I may have some Trail Magic to disperse to the hikers wanting it.

While Iâ€™m out that way, Iâ€™ll probably visit some Civil War sites, Iâ€™ll see.

Good Luck to all the hikers on the trail.

I never thought I would say, â€œIâ€™m looking forward to having surgeryâ€, but I am.

There was time I counted down the days before starting a hike, I even had an online account with a â€œcount-downâ€ clock.Â  Now, Iâ€™m counting down the days until July 11, when I go in to have (2) cervical disks removed.Â  These disks have bone spurs that are poking into my spinal cord and affecting my ability to walk correctly.

Even though thereâ€™s significant damage in my Lumbar region as well, my neurosurgeon seems to think that correcting the problem in my neck may take care of my walking problem.

He told me I wouldnâ€™t be able to drive for the first week, but after that, I shouldnâ€™t have any problem.Â  He also said I would be in a neck collar for (3) months, but that I could take it off to shower and shave.

Having been inactive for the past three years has been a tough pill for me to swallow.Â  Iâ€™m looking forward to the day I can shoulder my pack once again and take off on a hike.

Stay tunedâ€¦.

Monday, July 11, I went to Grant Hospital in Columbus, OH, and had an Anterior Cervical Discectomy on the C3/C4 and C4/C5 vertebrae.Â  I was released Tuesday wearing a neck collar, which Iâ€™ll have to wear for the next 3 months. Â I can remove it to shave and shower, so thatâ€™s alright.

Before my release, my neurosurgeon came to my room and got me up for a walk.Â  He told me to look ahead and to swing my arms when I walk.Â  I was amazed, I had NO Gimpy Legs!!Â  He went on to say, â€œfor the next 3 months I want you to walk every day and I donâ€™t care if you walk 100 times a day, walk and swing those armsâ€.

He told me the arm swings help with oneâ€™s balance.Â  I never had given that a thought before.Â  Well, being a hiker I have no problem following the Drâ€™s. orders.

Who knows, perhaps by this October, I can get out for some nice Fall Hikes here in Ohio

The way Iâ€™m feeling right now, Iâ€™m looking at either a â€œFlip-Flopâ€ hike or a LASH for 2023.

Currently, Iâ€™m in the healing and recovery stages of having an Anterior Cervical Discectomy done on July 11, 2022. 
I plan on starting in Harpers Ferry and hiking North.Â  As far as a starting date, I havenâ€™t set one yet.

Iâ€™ll have a friend drive me to one of the Amtrak Stops up North here in Ohio.Â  From there I can ride all the way into Harpers Ferry.

Please stay tuned as my plans and preparations come together.

Heeding the words of my neurosurgeon â€˜to walkâ€™, I grabbed my daypack, tossed in a bottle of water and a few snacks, and with neck collar/brace in place, I set off for Hocking Hills here in Ohio this past Thursday (08/25/2022).

My destination was â€œBig Pine Pillarâ€ or as some folks call it â€œBalancing Rockâ€.Â  The parking lot at the trailhead had two cars in it when I got there and the owners of them, were getting to leave, so I knew the trail would be all mine.

Not having done any hiking for the past 3 years and with the incline I wanted, I did make pretty good time getting up to the Pillar.

Being used to hiking with trekking poles, I opted not to take mine this time, remembering my doctor saying â€œswing your arm when you walkâ€.Â  I had a few places to navigate where the poles would have been handy, but I got through okay.

Iâ€™m ready for another one, maybe a little bit longer next time, this 2.02-mile hike got my appetite wet.



"Always pray to have eyes that see the best in people, a heart that forgives the worst, a mind that forgets the bad, and a soul that never loses faith in God"

In yesterday's entry, I mentioned hiking back to a favorite spot of mine in Hocking Hills, called "Big Pine Pillar" or as some folks call it, "Balancing Rock".Â  You can see from this picture that either name would be proper.

In just 2 days, it will be (9) weeks since I had my Anterior Cervical Discectomy on the C3/C4 and C4/C5 disks.Â  I can honestly say, Iâ€™ve never felt better.Â  I have absolutely no pain, I walk straight and upright with no limp.Â  I donâ€™t need the aid of a stick or cane, and when I walk, I swing my arms.

This past Tuesday, I went and had X-rays taken (per my neurosurgeonâ€™s request), and the results showed everything was perfect.Â  Iâ€™ll meet with the doctor now so he can show me the exercises he wants me to do.

Iâ€™m still in the neck collar/brace and will be until my doctor releases me from it, which Iâ€™m hoping, will be soon.

I would love to be out hiking or riding my bike more often, but since I have to wear this collar all of the time, even when sleeping, I know that after a few times of these types of activities, said collar would get to stink after a while.Â  The smell probably wouldnâ€™t bother me all that much, being a backpacker, but those around me, the city types, probably wouldnâ€™t appreciate it.

Iâ€™m still working on plans for either a â€œFlip-Flopâ€ hike out of Harpers Ferry or a LASH, next April.

Thanks for following along with me, and please stay tuned.
It was a gorgeous day for a walk, with no humidity, and a little breeze blowing.

I got another re-conditioning hike in yesterday over at John Bryan State Park/Clifton Gorge here in Central Ohio.I pause my Fit Bit app when I stopped for a break and when I started to hike again, I hit the wrong button so my map is in two sections.This is the first half of my hike.Â  I would post the other map with this journal entry, but I haven't figured out how to post more than one picture per entry.

I had an appointment today with my neurosurgeon and was given the "Great News" that I didn't have to wear my Neck Collar any longer.He did show me some exercises he wants me to do in order to strengthen my neck muscles and wants to see me in three months along with another set of X-rays.Now that our weather has started to cool off some, I want to get out and get some more hiking done and maybe take a nice long bike ride.I'm still making plans for an AT hike which I hope to start in April from Harpers Ferry.Â  I'm almost certain it won't be a Thru-Hike but a nice LASH would be fine with me.Â  We'll see how things go.

Yesterday 10/23/2022, was an absolutely beautiful day for a hike so I drove over to John Bryan State Park and hiked the "Miami River Trail".I didn't have any problems and I hiked at a pretty good pace in order to get a good cardio workout.When I set out on the AT next year, I have no desire to hike as fast as I did yesterday, I'll have all the time in the world to hike as far as these old bones and joints will let me.Today, I am experiencing quite a bit of pain and discomfort in my knees, so knee replacement surgery may be in my future.

Wow! Just (12) days and weâ€™ll be saying goodbye to 2022 and welcoming in 2023.Â  I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s just me but I think this year has flown by.

In looking at the journal entries for the â€œClass of 2023â€ I see a lot of variation in start dates and start locations but Iâ€™m sure weâ€™ll cross paths with each other someplace along the trail.

As of right now, Iâ€™m still planning on heading out to Harpers Ferry some time mid-April.Â  My plans are to head North and see how far these Old Bones and Joints will carry me.

If I can stay on the trail thru May I want to come home for a Southern Gospel Music Quartet concert on June 3rd.Â  â€œErnie Haase & Signature Soundâ€ are performing at the Ohio Star Theater up in Sugarcreek, OH.Â  I organize Outings and Events for the folks at the church where I attend and having seen this quartet once before, Iâ€™m hoping to take a group to see them again.

Providing Iâ€™m not experiencing any major knee problems by this time my plans are to return to the trail and see how far I can go.Â  I know a visit with the Orthopedic Specialist for a couple of Steroid Injections prior to starting out will help with my plans.

I just turned 71 on December 7th and I try to maintain an active lifestyle.Â  Even though Iâ€™m retired I enjoy helping others with projects they are doing.Â  I hike when I can as well as ride my bike.

I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever lose the passion for backpacking, however, the trips may not be as long as they once were just more frequent.

I would like to close this entry by wishing everyone the â€œHappiest of Holidaysâ€.Â  Also, â€œGood Luckâ€ and â€œHappy Trailsâ€ to the Class of 2023!!

See ya on the trail!!

I met with my neurosurgeon this past Friday, (1/13/23).Â  I had gotten some X-rays that he had ordered and having looked them over, he said everything looks â€œOKâ€.
Pointing to some shady areas on the X-rays he told me that this was new bone developing around the disks that he replaced back in July.Â  â€œThis is very goodâ€, he said.

I was told that I had NO Restrictions and that I could do anything I wanted.Â  When I told him about my hike this summer, he highly encouraged it.Â  He also said I had no weight restrictions for my pack, for me to carry whatever was comfortable.Â  So if the doctor says itâ€™s â€œOKâ€, it must be â€œOKâ€!

Iâ€™m to see him in July but when I said I could still be on the trail then, he told me to make an appointment when I get back.

Iâ€™m hoping to stay on the trail for as long as I can providing my knees hold up, I am having some trouble with them, but that comes with old age and the fact I was a long-distance runner in high school.

Iâ€™m definitely not going to be in a hurry this time so Iâ€™m hoping that will prevent any injury and allow me to remain on the trail.

It would be nice to have a compatible hiking partner but I usually hike with whoever happens to be in the same area as I am.Â  I know the trail will have other â€œFlip-Flopâ€ hikers starting at about the same time as me, so Iâ€™m sure there will be someone to hike with.

Iâ€™m still planning on getting a ride to Northern Ohio to one of several Amtrack Train Stations.Â  The train that passes through here goes right to Harper Ferry, W.Va., where Iâ€™ll be starting.

Please stay tuned as I await my start date and then follow along as I head up the trail.

With right around (78) days to go before I head North out of Harpers Ferry, W.Va., leastwise thatâ€™s my plans as of right now, I know that Iâ€™m not in any kind of shape.Â  It didnâ€™t take the Hocking Hills â€œWinter Hikeâ€ last Saturday to tell me that, I already knew it.

Iâ€™m hoping to get some more conditioning hikes in before my start date but if I donâ€™t I should be okay, as Iâ€™m not going to be in any hurry, plus there are no major elevations above 2000â€™ until Bear Mountain near the Mass./Conn. State line.

The last time I saw my Orthopedic Specialist, I was told that Iâ€™m a prime candidate for knee replacement because of my activity level.Â  He also said, because of my activity the steroid injections Iâ€™ve been getting in my knees will keep on working for me if I choose to keep getting them.

I heard an advertisement on the radio that a person could avoid knee replacement surgery just by getting fitted with proper â€œarch supportsâ€.Â  I think Iâ€™ll pay a visit to our local Good Feet Store to see what they have to say.Â  I know these arch supports are expensive but not as expensive as replacement surgery will be and they are pain-free unless you consider the pain in your wallet.

Iâ€™ll be ordering the updated version of ATCâ€™s â€œThru-Hikerâ€™s Companionâ€ and â€œData Bookâ€ before long.Â  I like to figure out somewhat of a plan for resupply, shelter/campsite stops, and interesting things to see along the trail, for example (Gettysburg and Hershey, Pa.)

There is a good stealth campsite at Pa. 325 (Clarks Valley), with room enough for 3 to 4 tents.Â  I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s listed in the newer publications, but I checked with the folks that maintain the trail in this section a few years ago otherwise itâ€™s 18 miles between Peters Mountain Shelter and Rausch Gap Shelter.

Good luck to those that have started already and to those that will be starting soon, perhaps our paths will cross somewhere along the trail.
I'm just sitting here reading some trailjournals.com entries and read the one concerning using a phone for placing a entry, so I thought I'd give it a try.Â Now to see if it will take.

In the years past I would take my Thru Hikers Companion, stick it in the microwave for 15 to 20 seconds at a time in order to soften the glue that bound it together.Â Once I had it apart the pages for the section I was hiking first would go in a zip lock bag.The rest of the book would go in a "Bounce Box" that I would send ahead of me.I had it figured out that when I was completing a section my box would be there so that I could swap out the sections.Â This did help reduce my pack weight.

I had a Gift Card and my dividends for REI burning a hole in my pocket, and not one for liking holes in my pockets, I went and took care of that.Being the "Gear Head" that I am, what I could do with an unlimited budget when I walk into one of their stores.Â  This trip was a breeze, it only cost me $6.36, not counting the gas it took to drive up.Â Â I saw an Ursack "AllMitey" that I would like to have.Â  Weighing just 13oz., and being bear and critter-proof, it would beat carrying the weight of a Bear Canister.Â  They are somewhat pricey, but if it would keep a bear or some other woodland creature from getting to my food, it would probably be worth it.Â  (I've been backpacking for 50 years and have yet to see a bear while on any trail.)I do like the food choices when it comes to the dehydrated prepared meals, but I can't afford to exist on them alone.Â  I carry a few of them but most of my meals can be resupplied using the groceries along the trail.

I'm not sure who the author is of this list or how up-to-date it is, as I came across it, October 27, 2020.Â  I thought it might be helpful for those preparing to head out to the trail.Appalachian Trail Resupply Points

One of the most confusing topics for new Appalachian Trail thru-hikers to plan as they attempt to coordinate their adventure is how to figure outÂ the right amount of food to last betweenÂ resupplies. An unfortunate effect is that many hikers start out carrying way too much food weight. This can evolve from a minor toÂ a major problem, and too frequentlyÂ causes injury early on in a hike because not only are your legs not ready for endurance walking up and down strenuous mountains, but theyâ€™re also ill-prepared to manage the weight ofÂ an extra 30-40 pounds.

Pre-hike tip #1: Buy ATCâ€™s â€œThru-Hikerâ€™s Companionâ€. Â Plan to start at a 10-mile-per-day pace the first week of your hike until you learn your limits as a hiker.

Pre-hike tip #2: As you start your northbound journey, if starting at Amicalola, plan for four days of food. Â For each day, plan a breakfast, a second breakfast, lunch, two afternoon snacks, and a substantial dinner including protein. Add some comfort chocolate or other goodiesÂ if you prefer. If your food bag weighs more than ten pounds leaving north from Springer or Amicalola, youâ€™re carrying more food than you will need to get to your first easy resupply point.

Listed below are the best resupply points along the Appalachian Trail. Â With a few exceptions, AT hikers will rarelyÂ go more than 50 miles without a resupply option.Â 

Mile 31 â€“ Mountain Crossings:Â A full-service outfitter with full resupply, the trail will run you right into the front door of this first stop along the trail. Â As mentioned above, you donâ€™t need more than four days of food to get you here.

Mile 52 OR 69 â€“ Hiawassee, GA: If you stay at Top of Georgia hostel,Â 706-982-3252, [GC1]Â multiple shuttles are available into town. Budget Inn,Â 706-896-4121 in Hiawassee is another lodging option thatÂ will come pick you up and deliver you back to the trail if you choose to stay there.

Mile 110 â€“ Franklin, NC: At Winding Stair Gap, US 64, hitch a ride into Franklin. Or call Havenâ€™s Budget Inn at 828-524-4403 and see if they can pick you up. While in town, visit the Lazy Hiker Brewing Company and Rock House Lodge to celebrate exiting your first state! Â You can also resupply atÂ Gooder Grove Hostel & Adventure Ctr.

Mile 137 â€“Nantahala Outdoor Center:Â No hitch required! NOC outfitters is on site with gear and food resupply.

Mile 164 â€“ Fontana General Store:Â Located 2 miles west of the A.T. from the point you cross Hwy 28. The trail takes you right to the visitorâ€™s center which offers snacks, but I wouldnâ€™t call it a full resupply. Â This is your last chance to print your Smokies permit and to resupply before entering the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

Mile 207 â€“ Newfound Gap, Gatlinburg: A shuttle or hitch is definitely required to make it 15 miles from here intoÂ Gatlinburg, but if youâ€™ve never experienced the city, itâ€™s worth the trip! Resupply options, honestly, arenâ€™t as great as youâ€™d expect in a town with so much to offer, but thereâ€™s enough to be found at pharmacies and the tiny grocers on the strip to make it another few days on trail. Â Unique experiences, a plethora of food, and Smoky Mountain BreweryÂ are a few notable mentions in town.

Mile 241 â€“Standing Bear Farm Hostel,Â off of Green Corner Road: Though certainly not a Walmart, this hostel offers adequate resupply options as you exit the Smokies.

Mile 274 â€“ Hot Springs, NC:Â The white blazes lead you right through this awesome trail town! With several hostel options including Elmers, 828-622-7206 and Laughing Heart, 828-206-8487, and several resupply spots in town, Bluff Mountain Outfitters,Â Â 828-622-7162, and Dollar General.

Mile 342 â€“ Erwin, TN, Â The trail leads you right to Uncle Johnnyâ€™s doorstep. He runs a popular hostel with complete outfitter and resupply. Â When you stay, he also shuttles you into town for free. Â 423-735-0548

Mile 367 â€“ Greasy Creek Hostel,Â phone 828-688-9948 â€“ Small resupply offered at this off-trail hostel.

Mile 393 â€“ Mountain Harbour Hostel,Â 866-772-9494 â€“ Only a 0.3 mile walk off trail, a small resupply is offered here.Â This would be a great place to mail yourself a resupply box!

Mile 421- Hampton, TN, Â Take the beautiful, creekside, 1 mile side trail into Hampton, TN. Â Resupply options are a bit limited, but there is a Dollar General and a couple of small grocers in town.

Mile 469 â€“ Damascus, VA:Â Â Welcome to Virginia, the self-proclaimed â€œState for Loversâ€. Â The blazes walk you straight through the heart of this trail town. Â Several hostels are available if you choose to stay in this popular trail town. Â The Place at 276-475-3441, Crazy Larryâ€™s at 276-274-3637, and Woodchuck Hostel, 406-407-1272 are just a handful of whatâ€™s available. With three outfitters in town plus a couple of grocers, an ample resupply is available here. Â Only a short walk out of town is the Damascus Brewery for beer lovers.

Â 

Mile 532 â€“ Marion, VA:Â The spot where the AT crosses VA 16 is a 6 mile hitch into Marion, VA. There are plenty of large grocery chains and restaurants in Marion. Thereâ€™s even a drive in movie theater! Hmmm, I wonder if they accept walk-ins. ğŸ˜‰

Mile 543 â€“ Atkins, VA: The trail leads you to the east side of Atkins where youâ€™ll find a Shell Convenience store. Â Limited resupply available here.

Mile 590 â€“ Bland, VA: just over three miles off trail, Bland offers a supermarket and a Dollar General as well as a few restaurants.

Mile 608 â€“Â Trentâ€™s Grocery:Â Only a half mile off trail, Trentâ€™s offers food, camping, showers, and a small resupply. 276-928-1349

Mile 634 â€“ Pearisburg, VA:Â Less than a mile to walk from trail to town, Pearisburg is worth a visit. In town youâ€™ll find lots of grocers for resuppply and every hikerâ€™s favorite, an all-you-can-eat Chinese buffet!

Mile 702 â€“ Catawaba, VA: Donation-based Four Pines Hostel, 540-309-8615, is an easy 0.3 of a mile road walk from the A.T. They offer shuttles to Catawaba Grocery and the Homeplace Restaurantwhen it is open.

Mile 729 â€“ Troutville, VA: Eight tenths of a mile from the trail is the town of Troutville complete with a Kroger grocery store and outfitter. Â Troutville also offers a relatively new brewery within walking distance, Flying Mouse Brewery, along with many lodging options.

Mile 784 â€“ Glasgow, VA: Glasgow isnâ€™t the easiest place to hitch a ride into town based on my experience, but patience usually pays off. Â There are small grocers in town and a free,town-provided pavilion with hot showers, a porta-potty, and tenting allowed.

Mile 806 â€“Buena Vista, VA: Nine miles off trail is the little town of â€œB-yoo-nu-Vistaâ€, as the locals pronounce it. With a Food Lion and several reasonable hotels, a campground, and restaurants, youâ€™ll find what you need for a full resupply.

Mile 861 â€“Waynesboro, VA:Â Â 4.5 miles off trail, Waynseboro is a hiker-friendly trail town offering a YMCA center for camping and showers, two hiker hostels, an outfitter, and plenty of large market options. Â The best thing about Waynesboro is Ming Garden, an all you can eat lunch and dinner Chinese restaurant. Yes, please.

As you enter Shenandoah National Park, prepare to be spoiled. Â There are stores/restaurants/bars throughout the park called â€œWaysidesâ€ which offer various resupply options and a limited outdoor selection. You wonâ€™t need to carry as much food as normal if you plan to capitalize on the meals offered at the Waysides.

Mile 890 â€“ Loft Mountain Wayside:Â Breakfast, lunch, and dinner is served. Â Food resupply items in store.

Mile 915 â€“ Lewis Mountain Campground and store: Home of the $1 cans of beer! You can even purchase singles of the good stuff for cheaper than you can purchase a can of soda. Charge your phone and enjoy a couple of drinks while you peruse the small resupply selection.

Mile 923 â€“ Big Meadows Wayside: Meals served and small resupply options available here. Great bar downstairs!

Mile 931 â€“ Skyland Resort and Restaurant: The gift shop on site sells basic resupply items. Thereâ€™s a bar on site.

Mile 941 â€“ Luray, VA: At US 211, if you can land a 9 mile hitch into town, Luray is a fun place to chill for a day or two. Ample restaurants and a few large and small markets in town, bowling and a movie theater, this city offers plenty of off-trail fun!

Mile 950 â€“ Elkwallow Wayside: Visible from where the trail crosses Skyline 23.9, youâ€™ve only got a 0.1 of a mile walk to reach Elkwallow. Â Breakfast, lunch, and dinner servedÂ on site and limited groceries available.

Mile 969 â€“ Front Royal, VA: Front Royal is a pretty easy place to hitch a ride from US Hwy 522. There are tons of options for food and resupply in Front Royal. Â The Front Royal Hostel is half a mile off trail at mile 965. Free morning shuttle into town with stay. 540-539-0509

Check out Bears Den Hostel and Blackburn AT Center for lodging options between miles 1002-1010. Read about them here. (Page 96 and 97)

Mile 1023 â€“ Harpers Ferry, WV:Â Â Celebrate your â€œalmostâ€ halfway point as the trail takes you directly into this unique little trail town! Only a small percentage of thru-hikers make it this far! Â While in town, visit the Appalachian Trail Conservancyâ€™s headquarters and have your picture made for the yearly album. Â There are a few small stores and restaurants in town for resupply and yumminess. Â This would be a good town to consider sending yourself a resupply box as your options are a bit limited in town.

Mile 1054 â€“ Smithsburg, MD: One and a half miles west of the A.T., you can find a Food Lion and several restaurants in Smithsburg, MD.

Mile 1063 â€“ Waynesboro, PA: The trail takes you 2 miles from the townâ€™s Walmart and 4.5 miles from downtown with other resupply options.

Mile 1081 â€“ Fayetteville, PA: Walmart is 7 miles west of the A.T. and a couple of smaller markets lie within 2 miles from the trail. Stick out that thumb and smile!

Mile 1101 â€“Pine Grove General Store:Â The trail leads you right past Pine Grove General store, most famous for its half-gallon challenge where hikers attempt to eat that much ice cream in half an hour. Most regret it afterwards. Â Donâ€™t say I didnâ€™t warn you. There is short-term resupply offered here. Â 717-486-4920

Mile 1121 â€“ Boiling Springs, PA:Â Our beloved trail leads you right into the heart of Boiling Springs, PA. Â A few small food marts are in town. Allenberry Resort Inn and Playhouse, 800-430-5468, is a fun landing spot for a night with delicious food and a bar with a good beer selection.

Mile 1146 â€“ Duncannon, PA: This is yet another trail town where following the white blazes leads you straight through its heart. Â The Doyle is a must-stop, at least for a beer and a burger. Â Several small convenience stores in town for resupply. This would be an awesome town to send ahead a box to ensure you get what you need in a full resupply. Â A new article coming soon on how to coordinate mail drops. Will link.

Mile 1191 and 1193 â€“ Pine Grove, PA: A little over 3 miles off trail, there are small resupply options in Pine Grove, PA. Â A Dollar General and BGâ€™s Market, 570-345-0464, exist there for you to stock up on what you need.

Mile 1217 â€“ Port Clinton and Hamburg, PA: The trail takes you right through Port Clinton where landing a ride into Hamburg is a cinch if you stop into the Port Clinton Barber Shop to hang out a while. Hamburg offers a variety of yummy eating spots, a Walmart superstore, and aÂ Cabellas outfitter. Â Port Clinton allows hikers to set up tents or sleep inside the town pavilion. Respect it as a privilege and take care of the place on behalf of all of us out there.

Mile 1257 â€“ Palmerton, PA:Â  Only 1.5 miles off the A.T., Palmerton has it all. Â Full resupply and eating options in town.

Mile 1277 â€“ Wind Gap, PA: An easy 1 mile walk or hitch into town, Wind Gap offers a couple of lodging options and two food stores for resupply. Â Restaurants are varied.

Mile 1293 â€“ Delaware Water Gap, PA: This is a popular trail town for hikers to take a zero mile day. Â The white blazes take you right through the middle of town. A donation based church hostel is available in the center of town, The Church of the Mountain HostelÂ 570-476-0345. Please donateÂ what you can to thank this church for the amazing service they offer us! Â  In town is Sycamore Grillwith beer and wings specials, Edge of the Woods Outfitters for resupply, and a couple of small grocers.

Mile 1336 â€“ Port Jervis, NY: This town offers a Price Chopper and Shop Right market and is located 4.4 miles from the A.T. trailhead.

Mile 1345 â€“ Unionville, NY: Only a 0.7 mile walk off trail, this little town offers free hiker camping behind their post office. The two town markets are small but offer adequate food resupply options. Â Enjoy the pizza and tavern in town!

Mile 1356 â€“ Vernon, NJ: The town sits 2.4 miles off trail, but Clarity found it to be a pretty easy hitch to and from town. Â Thereâ€™s an A&P Grocery in town and several restaurants to satisfy your hiker hunger. St. Thomas Episcopal Church offers a donation-based hiker hostel. Â They put a lot of work and service into the hostel, so please leave a donation as a thanks. Their phone number is 973-764-7506.

Mile 1383 â€“ Harriman, NY: Harriman is 3.7 miles off the A.T. and offers lodging and grocers.

Mile 1403 â€“ Fort Montgomery, NY: One point eight miles off trail, you can eat and resupply here. Â Mobile Market and Chestnut Mart are small markets.

Mile 1448 â€“ Pawling, NY: 2.6 miles off trail, youâ€™ll mostly find eateries here, but there is a CVS and free camping in town Â and more options another 1.8 miles into Hannaford.

Mile 1467 â€“ Kent, CT: Only 0.8 mile off trail, Kent offers a couple of small resupply options, a spattering of restaurants, and Kingsley Tavern to quench your thirst.

Mile 1490 â€“ Falls Village, CT:Â  Check out Bearded Woods One-of-a-Kind Bunk & Dine for a well-deserved splurge! Â Resupply and shuttles to town are offered with stay. Â This place is architecturally beautiful, clean, and dinner and breakfast are provided. Â Reservations required. Â 860-480-2966

Mile 1499 â€“ Salisbury, CT: Ms. Maria Macabe and Vanessa Breton offer low cost bedrooms and showers for a night. The town has very limited resupply but several restaurants.

Mile 1520 â€“ Great Barrington, MA: An easy hitch off a busy highway, Great Barrington is a neat town. Everything you could possibly want to eat can be found in town from chain restaurants to local joints. Â Thereâ€™s a Price Chopper and a Walmart a short walk north of town.

Mile 1550 â€“ Lee, MA: Hitchhike the 5 miles into town if you want to visit Price Chopper for your resupply needs.

Mile 1569 â€“ Dalton, MA:Â  Follow the white blazes straight into Dalton past Sweet Peaâ€™s ice cream shop into town. There is a fair amount ofÂ resupply to be found in Dalton.

Mile 1578 â€“ Cheshire, MA: Our faithful blazes once again lead us through this tiny Massachusetts town. Â Resupply options are limited, but there are a couple of convenience stores to stock up on the basics.Â This would be a good place to consider sending yourself a resupply box.

Mile 1592 â€“ North Adams and Williamstown, MA: One direction takes you into Willamstown, 2.7 miles from the trailhead. Â The other direction will walk you about 2 miles into North Adams with stopping points along the way.

Mile 1610 â€“ Bennington, VT: Town is 3.4 miles from where the A.T. crosses VT 9.

Mile 1650 â€“ Manchester Center, VT: Though town is 5.4 miles from the trailhead, you get spit out on a main highway, so getting a ride is pretty simple. Â Green Mountain House, 330-388-6478, a clean hostel option in town, offers shuttles with stay. FireflyÂ gets Clarityâ€™s vote as the best pub food and beer in town. Â Resupply options include Price Chopper and other small markets.

Mile 1700 â€“ Rutland, VT: Due in part to this being the town where The Yellow Deli hiker hostel is located, folks passing by the A.T. are pretty quick to pick up a hiker looking for a ride into town. Within walking distance from the donation based hostel is a Walmart, Price Chopper, and even a movie theater if youâ€™re in need of a relaxing zero mile day. Clarity recommendsÂ Hopâ€™n Moose for dinner and delicious on-site brewed beer!

Mile 1704 â€“ Killington, VT: If youâ€™d prefer to walk into towns rather than hitching, Killington is a mere 0.6 of a mile off trail at VT 100 and has options Base Camp Outfitters offering gear and food resupply and a small deli/market exists in town.

Mile 1747 â€“ Hanover, NH: Youâ€™ll follow the white blaze right into the heart of it. Upon entering town, stop at Louâ€™sÂ for a free gourmet muffin, Ramuntoâ€™sÂ pizzeria for a free slice and an awesome beer selection, and a Co-op Food Store for substantial resupply. Thereâ€™s free camping north of Hanover in the woods at the trailhead.

Mile 1800 or mile 1816 â€“ North Woodstock and Lincoln, NH: In North Woodstock, thereâ€™s the Notch Hostel,Â 603-348-1483, and in Lincoln, though not mentioned in the trail guides, there is Chetâ€™s place, the most popular thru-hiker landing spot in the area. Â Resupply options are ubiquitous.Â Outfitters and Price Choppers among other resupply stations are located in town.

Mile 1870 or 1891- Gorham, NH: White Mountains Lodge and Hostel offersÂ free evening shuttle into town for resupply at Walmart. Various food options in town from an all-you-can-eat Chinese buffet to Salt Pub to get your drink fix.

Mile 1932 â€“ Andover, ME: Youâ€™ve made it into your last state! Congrats on being among the few who have done so. Â Andover is located 8 miles from the trailhead. Â Extensive resupply available at Pine Ellis Lodging, and they will pick you up for a fee. Also within walking distance in this tiny town are a couple of small general stores. Mills Market cooked up the best brick oven pizza I experienced on the entire trailâ€¦what a gas station surprise!

Mile 1969 â€“ Rangeley, ME: Rangeley marks the halfway latitudinal point between the North Pole and the Equator and is home to Sargeâ€™s PubÂ with good burgers and beer. The Hiker Hut and Farmhouse InnÂ are hostels in the area of this hiker-friendly town. The three outfitters in town are really your only option for resupply.Â This would be a good town for you to mail yourself a resupply box!

Mile 2001 â€“ Stratton, ME: Stratton offers several small markets for adequate resupply. The White Wolf Inn, Home of the 8oz Wolf Burger, also houses a fairly decent selection of beer on tap.

Mile 2038 â€“ Caratunk, ME: With two lodging options less than 2 miles from the trailhead, Caratunk is a good spot to stop for a night or two and mingle with your trail family. Â The Sterling Inn, 207-672-3333 offers extensive resupply options, reasonable lodging, and a breakfast buffet. Â In the opposite direction, Northern Outdoors sits 2 miles off trail and provides a free shuttle, use of shower, pool, and hot tub with or without stay, and offers rooms, cabin tents, and traditional tenting. Â Kennebec River Pub and Brewery is on site. Â Call for shuttles 800-765-7238.

Mile 2074 â€“ Monson, ME: This is a must-stop trail town before hikers enter the Hundred Mile Wilderness. Â With two great lodging options, Lakeshore House Lodging & Pub at 207-997-7069 and Shawâ€™s LodgingÂ at 207-997-3597, thereâ€™s no shortage of places to land for a night to hang with your buds as your time together draws near to an end. Â Resupply options are sparse, Peteâ€™s PlaceÂ (with a helluva good breakfast!)Â and Robinsonâ€™s are small general stores with enough options to get you through the wilderness. Â Monson is a great place to mail yourself a food drop!

Mile 2174 â€“ Millinocket, ME: Youâ€™ve done it! Â The Hundred Mile Wilderness is behind you and only Katahdin looms aheadâ€¦your final mountain on the Appalachian Trail! Â The Appalachian Trail Lodge, 207-723-4321, offers a fee daily shuttle from Baxter park in the afternoon. Â Ole Manâ€™s Gear Shop is on site, and theAppalachian Trail Cafe is located a block down the road offering happy hour specials on select beer.

Your final white blaze! Â The days of planning resupplies, hiking from morning til night, and pigging out in hiker towns are over. Â Real world sometimes sucks upon return! Hikers sometimes suffer from a bit of post-trail stress. Â Coming soon is an article on ways to be proactive so that your transition back to reality is as stressfree as possible. Â Cheers! Congrats! Â ğŸ™‚ You will never be quite the same.

Â [GC1]I believe Top of Georgia Hostel went out of business. I knew it was for sale.

This past Thursday it was unseasonably warm here in Central Ohio at 70 degrees.Â I decided to get a hike in, so I tossed some water and snacks in my day pack and headed down to Hocking Hills.Â My intentions were to hike from Big Pine Road, County Road 11, over to Old Man's Cave and then back.This would have given me around 7 miles.Â As the picture shows, I had 3.15 miles, that's one way. I also stopped a mile shy of reaching Old Man's Cave, I listened to my body and it said I was spent.Perhaps the next hike will have me going the entire distance both ways, we'll see ğŸ‘€!

In 2015 I set out on March 26, from Springer Mountain, GA., to â€œThru-Hikeâ€ the Appalachian Trail.Â  I made it to Pearisburg, VA, and even after early on in my hike, I contracted Norovirus and spent 4 days in a hospital in Murphy, NC.

During this hike, I experienced quite a bit of muscle tightness which forced me off the trail in Pearisburg.

Some said it was due to a lack of stretching and I admitted that I seldom stretched before starting each morning.Â  I also believe that was the early stages of the spinal problem that Iâ€™m dealing with now.

After returning home from the trail I started noticing a drag with my right foot then at a Chiropractor visit I said something about it.Â  The Chiropractor adjusted my L4/L5 vertebrae, it helped but didnâ€™t fix the problem.

An MRI showed significant damage in this area where surgery would be necessary to correct it.Â  The neurosurgeon I had at the time didnâ€™t want to operate, instead, he wanted me to try different methods of pain relief.Â  I wanted the problem FIXED.

I switched neurosurgeons and during my first consultation with the new doctor, he noticed a weakness in my upper limbs.Â  Another MRI (cervical region) showed bone spurs growing into my spinal cord.

I was to the point I could barely walk without being in pain and only with the aid of a cane or stick.Â  On July 11, 2022, surgery was done and I was pain-free when I walked and I didnâ€™t need a cane or stick.Â  I actually ran from the hospital over to the parking garage where my friend that came to get me had parked.

My neurosurgeon told me that the L4/L5 problem may be needed to be fixed in order to have complete â€œcorrectâ€ mobility.

I made plans to head over the Harpers Ferry this April to begin a â€œFlip-Flopâ€ hike or at least a â€œLASHâ€, but the way Iâ€™m moving now, I think it would be a Bust.

Instead, I think Iâ€™ll go down for Trail Days this year, and perhaps offer whatever service I can give to help other hikers fulfill their dreams of completing the trail.

Iâ€™m to see my Chiropractor again in July, so Iâ€™ll address the current situation of my mobility with him at that time.

Iâ€™m currently planning on going to Damascus, Va., for Trail Days this year.Â  Itâ€™s being held on May 19th-21st.

I live in Central Ohio and Iâ€™m willing to pick up any Thru-Hikers that are North of Damascus that are wanting to attend Trail Days on my way down and return them to the trail where I picked them up after Trail Days.

If there are any interested hikers wanting to do this, let me know via my Guest Book and arrangements can be made.

Iâ€™m willing to go down a few days prior to the Trail Days as well.

The start of my â€œFlip-Flopâ€ or â€œLASHâ€ hike from Harpers Ferry, W. Va., was supposed to have begun either today or tomorrow, however, the bones and joints in my body had other ideas which didnâ€™t involve backpacking.

I think in an earlier post, I wrote about concerns I was having with my right leg and foot.Â  Even with increased activity, Iâ€™m still having problems but they arenâ€™t to the point where Iâ€™m needing a stick or cane to be mobile as I needed a year ago.

Knowing and listening to my body, I think trying to start a backpacking trip the way I feel would not be a good decision on my part and definitely be a waste of time and money.

Iâ€™m to see the neurosurgeon in July for a â€œOne Yearâ€ follow-up, but I called the other day to set up an appointment and could only leave a message.

I did manage to get a 5.25-mile hike (walk) in yesterday out at the Scioto Grove Metro Park, beginning and ending it with plenty of stretching, which I know helped considerably. 
Now that our weather is much nicer, Iâ€™m going to increase my activity by riding my bike and hiking a lot more.

Perhaps after another set of steroid injections in both knees and a set of arch supports from the â€œGood Feet Storeâ€, Iâ€™ll feel like getting back out there.

For those of you that have been following my journal, you may be wondering what has happened to me.

I was to begin hiking in mid-April of this year, however, 3 to 4 weeks before my start date I noticed my right foot was wanting to drag when I walked.

I knew from last year the results of an MRI showed significant damage to my L4/L5 Vertabre that surgery was necessary to correct it.

The neurosurgeon I had then didnâ€™t want to do surgery until he exhausted all other means of fixing the problem.

Once I switched hospitals, doctors, and neurosurgeons, in January 2022, I began receiving the care I needed.

My new neurosurgeon said, he didnâ€™t see any results of the Cervical region of my spine on the MRI, even though I was told I received a complete MRI from the hospital where I was being treated at.

Once I had the Cervical MRI results, the new neurosurgeon discovered bone spurs on my C3/C4 and C4/C5 vertebrae that were protruding into my spinal cord.Â  July 11th of 2022 I had Cervical Discectomy surgery performed on these vertebrae.
Now my new neurosurgeon has ordered an updated MRI and X-rays for me and once he has these results he said he would have me come in for surgery consultation.

Iâ€™m still staying as active as I can, biking and hiking locally with hopes of returning to the AT or some other long-distance trail perhaps next year.

This coming Wednesday, July 12, 2023, Iâ€™ll be going in for an updated MRI and some X-Rays per my Neurosurgeonâ€™s orders.Â  The last MRI I had done showed significant damage to my L4/L5 vertebrae to where surgery would be necessary to repair them.
A Cervical MRI that I had done separately revealed bone spurs on my C3/C4 and C4/C5 vertebrae which were protruding into my spinal cord.Â  On July 11, 2022, I had these vertebrae removed and replaced with synthetic ones.

Now that Iâ€™m becoming â€œgimpyâ€ (again) on my right side, my neurosurgeon wants to repair the L4/L5 vertebrae and Iâ€™m ready to have them repaired.

Iâ€™m not a doctor but I believe by fixing these problems with my spine, it might correct the problems Iâ€™m having with my knees, I canâ€™t only hope it does.

So once the MRI and X-Ray results are back, Iâ€™ll be called in for Surgery Consultation, which could be as early as next month.

Thanks everyone thatâ€™s been following along with me on this journal and stay tuned for further updates.

In case those of you that have been following my journal wonder what has happened to me, Iâ€™ll give you a Readerâ€™s Digest version of whatâ€™s going on.

I was to begin either a â€œFlip-Flopâ€ style Thru-Hike or a LASH, in mid-April of this year.Â  A few weeks before I was to head out to Harpers Fery, I noticed my right leg starting to become â€œgimpyâ€ and that I was dragging my right foot.

I had surgery scheduled for August 16 but my insurance company denied coverage, saying that I would have to extinguish all other forms of treatment first.

I did physical therapy and had two epidural steroid injections in 2021 when there was just one vertebra that was problematic, neither of these treatments â€œfixedâ€ the problem.

Now, I have two vertebrae showing signs of closing around the spinal cord and a Neurosurgeon that will operate, unlike the one I had in 2021.

I appealed the insurance companyâ€™s decision and notified my Neurosurgeon and Chiropractor, so now I wait to see if coverage will be granted, as these doctors have spoken with them.

My mobility has gotten worse from what it was in April, so hopefully something will be determined soon and for the good.

Once Iâ€™m fixed up and can start backpacking again, Iâ€™ve been entertaining the idea of doing â€œFallâ€ Section Hikes.Â  I love the Fall Season and I think it would make for an enjoyable hike.

Please stay tuned!
